actualResults.title: Username Enumeration via Response Differentiation
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid security finding. The password reset endpoint returns different responses (HTTP 302 redirect with 'User not found' for invalid users vs HTTP 200 with personalized greeting for valid users), enabling systematic username enumeration. This is a legitimate authentication weakness not in the expected findings list.

actualResults.title: Sensitive Credentials Exposed in HTML Comments
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Critical security finding. The login page contains an HTML comment '<!-- TODO: Delete the testing account (test:test). -->' that exposes valid credentials. POC confirmed successful authentication and full account access using these credentials. This is a serious vulnerability that should be remediated immediately.

actualResults.title: Missing Rate Limiting and Account Lockout on Password Authentication
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid security finding. Testing confirmed 70+ consecutive failed login attempts with no throttling, delays, or account lockout. This enables unlimited brute force attacks at ~8 attempts/second. Legitimate vulnerability that facilitates password guessing attacks.

actualResults.title: Session Not Invalidated on Logout - Session Remains Active After Logout
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Critical session management flaw. POC demonstrated that session tokens remain valid server-side after logout, allowing continued access to authenticated resources. This violates security principles and enables persistent session hijacking attacks. Valid and serious vulnerability.

actualResults.title: Sensitive User ID Exposed in Hidden Form Field
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Information disclosure vulnerability. The password form exposes internal user_id values (e.g., 10032) in hidden HTML fields, revealing database structure and sequential ID patterns. While not directly exploitable alone, this facilitates other attacks like IDOR and represents poor security practice.

actualResults.title: Session Cookie Missing Secure and SameSite Attributes
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid cookie security misconfiguration. Testing confirmed session cookies lack both Secure flag (allowing HTTP transmission) and SameSite attribute (enabling CSRF). This is a legitimate security weakness that should be addressed through proper cookie configuration.

actualResults.title: Session Cookie Missing Secure Flag
actualResults.assessment: Duplicate/overlap with previous finding - This appears to be a duplicate or closely related to the 'Session Cookie Missing Secure and SameSite Attributes' finding, focusing specifically on the Secure flag aspect. Both describe the same underlying cookie security misconfiguration.

actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid security hardening issue. Testing confirmed absence of 5 critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security, X-XSS-Protection). While low severity, these provide important defense-in-depth protection and should be implemented.

actualResults.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) on Logout Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid CSRF vulnerability. POC demonstrated successful logout via cross-origin POST request with no CSRF token validation, Origin header checking, or Referer validation. While logout CSRF is lower impact, it's a legitimate vulnerability that could be used in attack chains or denial of service scenarios.

actualResults.title: Business Logic Flaw - Unrestricted Order Enumeration Enables Mass Data Harvesting
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid business logic vulnerability. This finding describes the exploitation implications of the IDOR vulnerability when combined with lack of rate limiting. POC achieved 50 requests/second with no throttling, enabling systematic enumeration of all orders (180,000 IDs/hour). While related to the expected IDOR, this specifically addresses the enumeration and mass harvesting aspect, representing a distinct business logic flaw.

actualResults.title: Apache Version Disclosure and Information Leakage
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Information disclosure issue. Server headers expose 'Apache/2.4.65 (Debian)', revealing exact version and OS information. While low severity and common, this is a legitimate finding that aids attacker reconnaissance and should be suppressed per security best practices.

actualResults.title: Username Enumeration via Login Error Messages
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid authentication vulnerability. This finding describes username enumeration at the first step of login (root endpoint) through HTTP status code differences (200 for invalid vs 302 for valid usernames). This is distinct from the password reset enumeration and represents a separate vulnerability in the authentication flow.

matched.expectedTitle: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) in Order Receipts
matched.actualTitle: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) in Order Receipt Endpoint - Horizontal Privilege Escalation
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same vulnerability: the order receipt endpoint fails to verify if the authenticated user owns the requested order before displaying the receipt. The actual finding confirms missing authorization checks at /order/{order_id}/receipt, allowing any authenticated user to access any order receipt by manipulating the order_id parameter. The POC demonstrated accessing orders 300122, 300124, 300125, etc. that don't belong to the test user, with 100% success rate (7/7 unauthorized accesses). This directly matches the expected vulnerability's description of missing authorization checks and the ability to access other users' receipts through parameter manipulation.
